Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor I have an appointment next Wednesday with a local urologist who is the senior partner in a large SW Florida practice. He wants to talk with my wife and I and review my PSA and family history as well as our attitudes and concerns. He will then recommend next steps. The practice website and patient testimonials indicate the use of pretty new technology and techniques. One of their more interesting diagnostic tools, from my perceptive, is the 4KScore blood analysis. I did a lot of professional work developing similar predictive scoring, based on historical measures, in a far different field. I have spent a lot of time studying the various validation studies for OPKO and 4KScore and think I have a good understanding of the advantages and potential problems. I have verified that Medicare will not pay the $400 cost of a 4KScore blood analysis. My other local option is to have a 3T Multiparametric MR Imaging & 3D Prostate Mapping procedure done by a different practice, which tells me is 100% covered by Medicare and my Florida Blue supplemental insurance. I am having trouble understanding the advantage of having the 4KScore , which only yields the probability of an aggressive cancer when the 3TMP MRI will actually show lesions and lumps and can subsequently be used for biopsy guidance in a fused situation. I like the idea of starting with another simple blood test but wonder what information I actually gain from that blood test. Does anyone have any 4KScore experience that can explain the 4KScore advantage over starting with a sophisticated MRI? The way my urologist put it to me, the 4KScore is another set of data to determine if a biopsy can be avoided or if in fact a wise idea to proceed. I did not pursue the 4KScore. An mpMRI is a procedure that was used after my biopsy in my case to help see if I was a candidate for active surveillance which I was at that point in time. It is also becoming popular prior to a biopsy as a way to see if a biopsy can be avoided. For the record, the mpMRI doesn't diagnose cancer only the biopsy does.
Posts.Title: 4kScore -vs- 3TMPMRI

Posts.Content: Consensus seems to indicate that positive cores on apex side is not as favorable as positive cores on base side. How much emphasis would you put on positive core location when determining when/if to proceed to the next course of action? I think I read something today that positive margins occur more on the apex side?
Posts.Title: Apex, Base and a discussion on positive margins

Posts.Content: I had experienced fevers after both my biopsies actually. However, because of a prior case of endocarditis, I was admitted both times and had a blood culture drawn each time. For each admission of 2 days, I was given IV antibiotics. Both times no infection was found for the record. Did he have a blood culture taken? It's sounds like he may have.
Posts.Title: Fevers after catheter removal

Posts.Content: Not the PSA trend I am hoping for. But the bright side is that I historically go up and down. More nervous about my upcoming biopsy.
Posts.Title: Latest PSA = 4.29. Follow up biopsy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: While I'm new to this board, I'm not new to health boards in general. I am on several heart boards, as I had a robotic mitral valve repair due to prolapse back in 2009. Even on those boards, which do a great service, get pretty heated especially when discussing which surgery technique should be used. Opinions on which is best whether open sternotomy, minimally invasive either with several (2") incisions or robotic with five (1/2") incisions. Then discussions that "my surgeon's" technique is better because with open sternotomy, he can see better. Yes, but it's messier and your hospital recovery is a lot longer. Then opinions that mitral valve surgery isn't as important/cool/newsworthy as the more common aortic valve which is kind of a bigger problem. But surgery is surgery. My robotic mv repair still involved stopping my heart and hooking me up to the heart pump machine for about 90 minutes. I asked my surgeon, does this machine have a backup battery. He smirked at me and said we got it covered and it doesn't happen. Boards are a good thing.
Posts.Title: Letter to the Editor: PCa Opinions are Becoming as Intense as Politics

Posts.Content: I think it's common to have a little blood in urine for a few days but my discharge instructions stated if you see clots tell the uro. The timeline suggests about 3 days has gone by. Of course not having full details, I would probably going to the ER. As far as semen, you can expect some blood possibly up to 6 weeks. Don't be waiting.
Posts.Title: Bleeding after Biopsy

Posts.Content: Well my PSA has in fact dropped back down to 3.49 after reaching a high of 12.76 two months after my biopsy. My followup MRI taken a week ago showed no focal abnormalities consistent with PI-RADS 3, 4, or 5 lesion. No evidence for extraprostatic disease, pelvic lymphadenopathy, or enhancing bone lesions. My surgical uro said good news and that previous lesions show to be a bit more insignificant. He actually commented that he thinks that the my 50% chance of needing intervention is more like 33%. Ok. Plan is to do quarterly PSA checks and repeat MRI in 12 months. I see my regular uro in March and I'm sure will be in agreement. I wouldn't have been due for a repeat bx until next year so we'll see. Moving right along.
Posts.Title: MRI and PSA update

Posts.Content: The rise to 12 is being considered a probable infection of some sort after the biopsy possibly at a microscopic level. I did run a fever and was admitted to the hospital for observation. My uro’s just think that my PSA is dynamic and it lives in the 4 area. They both say it can happen and don’t seem concerned. They are more concerned about stability.
Posts.Title: MRI and PSA update

Posts.Content: No manipulation. My data seems stable, why do you think 100%. I’m prepared for intervention if that time comes. Isn’t that the purpose of AS? I’ve checked your past responses relating to me and others and I sense something I can’t put my finger on. Do you think being on AS is fun? Or is AS not a valid discussion? I’ll be happy to pull this post. Perhaps I’ve outlived the usefulness of this board since AS is some kind of pseudo treatment.

Posts.Title: MRI and PSA update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DBosdad This is my second post, a little background on myself. I'm 49 yrs old, no family history in good general health, have some mild symptoms Once in a while I have a frequent need to go in evening from 6pm-10pm, always sleep through the night without the need to get up Some weak stream from time to time Back on April 6th during a general health exam I got a 6.11 ng/mL PSA I was referred to a a a Urologists who did a DRE which came back normal other than a slight enlargement, I don't have size results. Directly after the DRE I did another PSA blood test which came back at 3.54 ng/mL, I know having a DRE can artificially raise the PSA results, so this seemed like a good result. After that test I was put on antibiotic can't remember which one, for one month twice daily. A week after the month was done I got another PSA on 5/23, this time it came back at 4.58 ng/mL so we decided to get another PSA done a week later on 5/29 and we included free PSA reading and the results came back at PSA 8.92 ng/mL and Free PSA 0.92 ng/mL ng/mL % free psa 10.3 Now my Uro is planning a biopsy which I wanted to avoid A few questions, why are my results all over the place? Is it normal for PSA levels to vary that much in less than a 2 month time frame? Anyone have the same situations? Any thoughts, suggestions, input would be greatly appreciated. My PSA continues to be all over the place. Apparently it happens but I'm not sure what to make of your case. People have talked about prostatitis and BPH and the difficulty it is to treat. I'm not sure if that was discussed. I recall in my case before finally getting a biopsy talking about getting a 4k score test done which measures a few more components. I didn't get one done but it probably wouldn't have mattered in my case. Hopefully, someone will come along more versed than me with some better answers.
Posts.Title: PSA all over the place

Posts.Title: PSA all over the place

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Had a nice Christmas present today. The results of a 3T mp-MRI that was done at Johns Hopkins last week. I was in the tube for an hour as they did a 3D reconstruction study. The previous three MRI's had shown three lesions. The index one was first scored as a PIRADS 4 and the others as PIRADS 3. Then, later MRI's downgraded the 4 to a 3. This new result downgraded the original 4 to a 2 , and did not see the other two lesions. So, over the past ten years, my prostate cancer appears to have shrunk and regressed. This is not what I expected when I started out on this journey, but I'll gladly take it. Have to discuss having future biopsies with Dr. Carter. He insists on his protocol scheduled biopsies, and believes I need (a sixth) one for that reason. But I'm not sure that I see any benefit in having anymore, at least until other testing demonstrates a concern. First off Merry Christmas. Wow that's great news. I didn't think that was possible. Did you ask the doctors if they had any thoughts about that?
Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Thanks for the announcement Frank. Now get better!
Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: Im glad youre doing well. Your updates are helpful as this may be my future path. About 8 weeks after robotic mitral valve surgery, I had these odd moving pains in my upper body that my CT surgeon termed pleural effusion basically buildup of fluids in the tissues of lungs and chest. I was given warning that 20% of heart surgery patients may experience this and is treated by steroid pack taken orally. Not sure if this is what youre experiencing. I do feel your pain.
Posts.Title: 48-hours post RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Three of my five biopsies were no problem, and two resulted in pain, tripling of my PSA, and inflammation lasting for six months. The only thing that stopped the inflammation were sitz baths. So much for high-tech meds! If I were you, I would avoid any more biopsies unless you have an MRI with one or more PIRADS v.2 grade 4 or 5 lesions. But, that's only my opinion, and your doctors have suggested a plan that sounds as safe as they can try to make it. Hopefully this biopsy will show no change, or even less cancer. Good luck. Thanks. Your comment PIRADS v.2. Is that version 2? Is that a separate thing from version 1 or do you just mean PIRADS 4 and 5? I guess my head is not clear at the moment. My thought is that while in the past, I've been told that one can be on AS without being on a "technical" Program. I would think that there has to be some common ground so that I can be actively monitored yet maybe figure a way around the timing of future biopsies. My AS Study Program has me for a repeat in 2019 and then in 2021. I believe my regular Uro thought if nothing changes, possibly doing my next biopsy in 2020. Is this significant at this point? I'm not sure. I'll expect my call later on today.
Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Got it. TY! I misinterpreted 3/12 as March 2012 instead of the obvious "3 out of 12!" My stupidity!!! Re "What's on your mind?:" Not sure if prior mitral valve repair predisposes you to increased risks in the event of a systemic infection. If so, then prostate biopsy might have increased risks in your case. Also, the antibiotics given to prevent infection due to biopsy can cause major GI "infection" by allowing the gut to get overrun by c. diff. It has happened to several of your Forum Brothers (FBs). Thus prostate biopsy clearly has risks. Hope your risks will be rewarded with continued AS. MF With a history of endocarditis in 2014, Uro, ID and Cardio were on board. In fact, with any procedure, I get approval from both. I'm aware of my "special" situation. As my ID Dr. explained, all such temperature spikes require blood culture and immediate analysis to ensure it doesn't evolve into bacteria that would then go through the blood stream to the heart area. I suppose too much antibiotics is not good either, but I think the lesser of two evils seems to be the way I roll. In my case, it has to be figured out how I can manage or delay the biopsy without compromising the surveillance as long as the data indicates I'm still very low/low risk per AUA guidelines. I also don't want to have intervention if I don't need it (at the moment I don't) because I can't withstand a biopsy. But I feel it'll work out in the end.
Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate PIRADS v.2 is version 2, which is a different, improved, library of software than version 1. PIRADS scores of 1-5 are the grading system applied to areas that appear suspicious, and how likely they are to have significant cancer if the the prostate were to be remove and analyzed. Those areas (lesions) can be targeted in subsequent biopsies. AS programs are becoming more flexible about the scheduling of biopsies. You need to keep talking with your specialists, and maybe they will do alternative testing. Thanks ASA. Glad to hear about flexibility. Thanks for the version information. I was hoping to find out which version my mpMRI was by reading the report but I can't seem to determine it.
Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi ejc61 ! Re Your Signature line: "bx:3/12 positive; all 3+3=6;5%,5%,20%:" Was your 1st biopsy 6 years ago or last year? Based on your history, I'm surprised that Emory did not also consult a cardiologist. Would it have been better to simply repeat the mp MRI to identify any changes or new developments and then decide if biopsy was necessary? Fingers crossed for a favorable Path Report and continued AS! MF Dx biopsy was 3/2017. I do have a long standing cardiologist in the building next to my Uro and ID Dr. They are all kept in the loop and have worked together in the past. Why do you ask? Since I'm scheduled for the mpMRI this July, maybe its just a matter of order. Coordination is strange sometimes. Thanks.
Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Content: Well I had my confirmatory biopsy last Thursday. With last year’s biopsy, I had a temperature spike after premedication antibiotics and ultimate hospital stay for observation with no infection found. So this year, the premedication included the addition of 440ml of Gentamicin given as IV about 90 minutes before the biopsy. Once IV was done, biopsy to start. Biopsy went fine. 24 hours later, temp spiked to 102°F. Ordered to ER, blood cultures, chest X-rays and vancomycin IV was started. Because of my history of endocarditis, treated as a infection risk. My infectious disease Dr and urologist both on top of the situation, and I see both in the hospital. As of yesterday, blood cultures and white blood count negative. I was diagnosed with having systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). So I’m 2 for 2 with fever spikes after biopsy yet negative cultures. ID Dr says it does happen. Her concern is that bacteria doesn’t develop into the bloodstream and then to the heart. I’ve had mitral valve repair. Both times I was not a sepsis kind of case. My ID Dr. is thinking that the next biopsy I need to have, I may just be admitted for observation straight from the procedure. My ID Dr and Uro know each other very well and are in the same building. May have to ask for a meeting of the minds. I left the hospital yesterday and just took off today. I hope to have the path report tomorrow.
Posts.Title: re: confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18 snag

Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: The number of cores question has been debatable for sure as ASA has pointed out. Thanks for posting this DjinTonic. I think I fall somewhere between #7 and#8 at the moment. A few weeks ago, Dr. Sanda was emphatic that AS was still right for me. Assuming my last PSA of 12.67 taken 10 weeks after biopsy was a fluke and came after my appointment with him.
Posts.Title: AUA/ASTRO/SUO Guideline for Clinically Localized Prostate Cancer (2018)

Posts.Content: So far my only experience is that my PSA jumps around a bit. I think about that myself.
Posts.Title: From Slow Growth to Rapid Growth - Anyone experience this?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another A second opinion on the samples from Epstein's lab at Hopkins may be a good idea to confirm no G4, again. Volume, PSA velocity, and density all factor in. My G6 was high volume with increasing velocity and upgraded to G3+4 after removal. One thing I've been learning is the risk of hanging everything on one good factor, such as your G6. Your PSA is bouncing around a lot. Are you messing with it? Just askin'. I'd say your age is a factor as well and you are heading for treatment. The risk increases the longer you wait, imo. If treatment is inevitable why wait? You're doing a good job staying on top of this. Thanks. Yes I'm working on getting a second from JH. There is no understanding of my PSA movement. Always total monk mode 7 days before. I'm thinking about intervention a little more than last year to be honest. I'm due for an mpMRI in July. Maybe do that first. I'll be having more detailed conversation with my doctors for sure.
Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: So I got the call from my Urologist earlier today. 4 cores positive out of 12. Each positive core was 3+3=6. The positive core involvement was 5%, 5%, 20%, 30%. He said the placement was pretty scattered. Also mentioned something called Atypia. I forgot to ask the prostate size but he's mailing me the report. I'm also trying to get the office to fax it to me. He's thinking re-biopsy in 2 years. I'm due for a followup mpMRI this July. I tend to have difficult biopsies. He just wanted me to process this, but I'm thinking I may still be OK to stay on AS safely. I'm going to set up a consult meeting with him to discuss further.
Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: Comparing my bx from last year and this year. Bx 3/17: RLBase GS6 5%. LMid GS6 20%. LLApex GS6 5%. Bx 4/18: RLBase Atypical. RLApex GS6 5%. RApex GS6 5%. LApex GS6 20%. LLApex GS6 30%. Look like a lot of stuff on Apex end. MpMRI lesions in 7/17 both in RL Base. Just sayin.
Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi ej61! Educational Question: Is your Emory AS protocol a general guideline or is it a definitive protocol that your URO MD specifically tailors to you as a patient? i.e. Are there specific metrics that if/when reached, AS is cancelled and treatment commences? If there are specific metrics, please share. e.g. - PSA - PIRADS - Genomic Test Results You are doing a great job of staying on top of your status. At some point, intervention will likely be required. Hoping that newer "biologic" treatments will be available when that metric is reached. MF Thanks for the encouragement. My regular Uro had introduced me to my Uro surgeon and RO team last year just to get another perspective. Total team approach. After last year's results, the surgeon who is the Chairman of the Dept of Urology at Emory School of Medicine thought I looked good for a study program and had in his mind, a planned out 2-3 year AS. Both Uro's were pretty strong on me taking the AS route "for now" last year. My understanding is that while AS "programs" sort of follow the same guidelines, my whole mindset was I want to make sure I'm being watched closely and following AUA guidelines. Their philosophy and metrics seem consistent with accepted guidelines. What they are looking for is PSA <10, negative DRE, GS 6, involvement < 50% in any core nothing earth shattering. Not sure if 4 positive cores is a problem since its still under 34%. MRI last year and this year. They do take Pi-Rads 4 and 5 serious. Didn't get that concerned with Pi-Rad 3. I suspect testing frequency may change as time goes on. As far as Genomics, they seem to feel that it's helpful as extra data and may make the patient sleep better at night, but it won't influence their decision. Given the fact that I have problems with fever spikes after biopsy's, I'm hoping that something can be tailored for me.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis May want to consider one of the genomic tests if you want more information about the probability of metastasis. I did the Decipher test. Denis My OncoDX last year was 19. The price tag is steep and I'm not sure if it will sway my decision as much. It helped last year but I have a bit more data now.
Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: So I got the call from my Urologist earlier today. 4 cores positive out of 12. Each positive core was 3+3=6. The positive core involvement was 5%, 5%, 20%, 30%. He said the placement was pretty scattered. Also mentioned something called Atypia. I forgot to ask the prostate size but he's mailing me the report. I'm also trying to get the office to fax it to me. He's thinking re-biopsy in 2 years. I'm due for a followup mpMRI this July. I tend to have difficult biopsies. He just wanted me to process this, but I'm thinking I may still be OK to stay on AS safely. I'm going to set up a consult meeting with him to discuss further.

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another A second opinion on the samples from Epstein's lab at Hopkins may be a good idea to confirm no G4, again. Volume, PSA velocity, and density all factor in. My G6 was high volume with increasing velocity and upgraded to G3+4 after removal. One thing I've been learning is the risk of hanging everything on one good factor, such as your G6. Your PSA is bouncing around a lot. Are you messing with it? Just askin'. I'd say your age is a factor as well and you are heading for treatment. The risk increases the longer you wait, imo. If treatment is inevitable why wait? You're doing a good job staying on top of this. Thanks. Yes I'm working on getting a second from JH. There is no understanding of my PSA movement. Always total monk mode 7 days before. I'm thinking about intervention a little more than last year to be honest. I'm due for an mpMRI in July. Maybe do that first. I'll be having more detailed conversation with my doctors for sure.

Posts.Content: Comparing my bx from last year and this year. Bx 3/17: RLBase GS6 5%. LMid GS6 20%. LLApex GS6 5%. Bx 4/18: RLBase Atypical. RLApex GS6 5%. RApex GS6 5%. LApex GS6 20%. LLApex GS6 30%. Look like a lot of stuff on Apex end. MpMRI lesions in 7/17 both in RL Base. Just sayin.

Posts.Content: I would say because Im being actively watched. Im not taking any supplements other than multivitamin, fish oil, added iron recently because Ive been vegetarian for a year.

Posts.Title: Results of confirmatory biopsy 4/19/18

Posts.Content: My PSA jumped to 12.76 on Wednesday. Last reading in April was 4.29 prior to my biopsy. I did run a fever after biopsy but infection ruled out. Maybe 10 weeks was too soon for my quarterly draw? Ruined my encouraging consultation on that day. Not panicking.
Posts.Title: Unusual rise in first PSA since April Biopsy

Posts.Content: After my confirmatory biopsy in April 2018, my subsequent PSA in late June was 12.76 and PSA last week was 9.88. I did develop a 102 fever and a case of SIRS after the biopsy even with heavy pre-medication. I have an ID Doctor who I consult with who did a blood culture which turned out negative. I have an ID doctor because I have a history of endocarditis. I had a followup with my urology surgeon Dr. Sanda at Emory as well as the Rad Onc yesterday. He is interested in the PSA rise obviously and is thinking some kind of prostatitis is involved. He went on to explain that there are 3 basic types of prostatitis, some with symptoms, some without symptoms, and some that is a combination of something you only see at the microscopic level. My nurse wife understood it so I'm good with that. He says my PSA is "dynamic" and he does see that in patients. Basically, while he doesn't think I'm out of the woods, he noted the 25% decrease from June to August. The plan is for me to recheck my PSA in Oct/Nov and then one in December, (outside of the 3-6 month interval to make us feel better.) Basically if it goes down, it would be good. If the PSA goes back up, which would put it at 10+, all bets are off and then treatment will be talked about. Also, my MRI scheduled for next April will be moved closer to January. Both he and the Rad Onc are pretty booked up through the end of the year. Having this extra data in the next quarter is going to tell alot. Dr. Sanda even said if it was him with this data history, it would be what he'd do. Ok I'll take that under advisement. To be continued...
Posts.Title: Update on my status - 8/23/18
